question: Christ, what a pit. Phil" The sleeping figure rouses himself and looks out at Hawley. It's Phil, the .Channel 9 Action News weatherman. It's February first, Phil. You know what tomorrow is? Phil sits up and.thinks hard. He's in his mid-thirties, smart, rugged-looking, perhaps a little too full of himself, but clearly a guy with a lot of personality.
answer: Oh, no! Not again. He jumps up and exits the office with Hawley right behind him. Forget it! I'm not going. Get away from me. I'm working.

question: So what's the outlook? We gonna get that blizzard? Phil shakes his head and points to the chart which is headed "Phil's Phorecast" with a cute caricature of himself drawn next to the title.
answer: No way. All that moisture coming up from the Gulf is going to miss us completely and take a dump on Harrisburg.

question: Good, 'cause you're going up to Punxsutawney to cover the groundhog story tomorrow morning and I want you back here in time to do the five.
answer: Jesus, Gil, give me a break, will you! I covered the goddamn groundhog last year and the year before that.

question: And you'll do it :next year and the year after, too. When I worked in San Diego, I covered the swallows coming back to Capistrano for ten years in a row.
answer: You should've killed the guy who made you do that.

question: I wanted to do it.
answer: Then you should've killed yourself. I don't want to get stuck with the groundhog for the rest of my life.

question: It's a cute story. He comes out, he looks around, he wrinkles up his little nose, he sniffs around a little, he sees his shadow, he d oesn't see his shadow-- it's nice. People like it.
answer: Many people are morons.

question: Just do it.
answer: What'11 you give me? Hawley looks across the studio and sees RITA HANSON enter, a very attractive segment producer in her late twenties.

question: Yeah, okay. Hawley exits leaving Phil and Rita alone in the studio. She knows Phil mainly by his reputation and it isn't good. Still, she finds him appealing in an odd way. I've never done a weather story before. What's Punxsutawney like?
answer: Oh, it's an enchanted place. A magical world. It's the Constantinople of the whole Western Appalachian-Susquehanna Drainage system.

question: Do you always joke?
answer: About 70 to 80% of the time. Inside I'm actually a very shy and sensitive person.

question: A lot of people around here think you're not very sincere.
answer: Tell me the names of these people.

question: I'll line up a crew and transportation. If you don't feel like driving, we can all go up in the van together.
answer: I think I'll take my own car. I ' m not that fond of my fellow man. Nice face. Why don't you ride up with me?

question: No, thanks. STEPHANIE DECASTRO , an attractive, dark-eyed, dark-haired correspondent, glares at Phil from across the studio.
answer: They don't really think of me as a weatherman around here. More of a "personality," but with the credibility of a first-class broadcast journalist. Once you look at my tape I think you'll see what they mean. Stephanie enters and stands in the doorway looking at Phil for a long moment. There is something vaguely off-center about this woman, not quite FATAL ATTRACTION but still a little scary. Dan, can I call you back? I've just been handed something and I better get on it... ...Okay, thanks.

question: They don't really think of me as a weatherman around here. More of a "personality," but with the credibility of a first-class broadcast journalist. Once you look at my tape I think you'll see what they mean. Stephanie enters and stands in the doorway looking at Phil for a long moment. There is something vaguely off-center about this woman, not quite FATAL ATTRACTION but still a little scary. Dan, can I call you back? I've just been handed something and I better get on it... ...Okay, thanks.
answer: Everybody says that at the beginning of a relationship.

question: (gently pushing her
answer: Are you saying our relationship was a waste of time?

question: Our relationship? We went out a total of four times! And only twice did anything happen. It was fun but I don't see that as a big commitment.
answer: I had our charts done. My astrologer says we're extremely compatible. There may even be some past lives involvement here.

question: See? So we've already done this. Let's move on. Next case.
answer: You know what's wrong with you, Phil? You're selfish. You don't have time for anyone but yourself.

question: That's what I ' m trying to tell you. You don't want to be with me. You can do better. Look, Stephanie, if I ever said or did anything to mislead you I'm sorry for that, but right now I have to do this groundhog thing and I don't have a handle on it yet. He throws some papers and his datebook into a briefcase and puts on his jacket. I'll tell you what. I ' m going to do some serious thinking while I ' m in Punxsutawney, okay? He pats her on the shoulder and brushes past her, leaving her standing there with a malevolent look on her face. I'm on my way to Punxsutawney... Punx^su-taw-ney....Work or fun? I think that all depends on you. . . . . I thought maybe you could meet me up there tonight and let me vulgarize you for about seven hours....So I ' m supposed to spend the night in Punxsutawney all alo ne? Thanks. Rita! I can't stay here. Rita is already helping Larry unload equipment from the van.
answer: It's okay. I'll handle it. She crosses to the Lexus where Phil is trying to make another call on his earphone. What's the problem, Phil?

question: I hate this place. I stayed here two years ago and I was miserable. It's like a minimum security prison. I'm not staying here.
answer: You're not staying here. No, Larry and I don't care but I thought you might, so I booked you at a very nice bed and breakfast on Cherry Street. Here's the address. She hands him a card. Whatever I can do.

question: Really? Will you be my love slave?
answer: Whatever I can do within reason. Would you like to have dinner with Larry and me?

question: No thanks, I've seen Larry eat. Why don't you ditch Larry and let me take you someplace nice?
answer: You mean like a date?

question: Yeah.
answer: Oh, no.

question: Okay. I get it. You're a little intimidated by me, you're all excited about the shoot tomorrow, you want everything to go just perfect. I understand. You just get some sleep. Tomorrow will be great.
answer: Well, that's something to look forward to. I'll see you in the morning. He drives off, leaving her standing there shaking her head.

question: Okay, campers, rise and shine, and don't forget your booties because it's COOOLD out there Not hardly. And you can expect hazardous travel later today with that, you know, blizzard thing--
answer: That "blizzard thing?" Phil splashes some water on his face and prepares to shave. Oh, here's the report

question: Yes they are, but there's another reason today is very special--
answer: Es pec ia lly cold--

question: Especially cold, okay, but the big question on everybody's lips--
answer: Ch ap pe d lips--

question: :--on their chapped lips, right-- Do you think Phil's going to come out and see his shadow?
answer: Punxsutawney Phil. Phil looks up at himself in the mirror, admiring his own face.

question: Never again.
answer: Morning .

question: Morning .
answer: Think it'll be an early Spring?

question: I ' m predicting March 21st.
answer: Did you sleep well, Mr. Connors?

question: Like a Roumanian orphan, Mrs. Lancaster.
answer: Would you like some coffee?

question: I don't suppose it1 d be possible to get an espresso or a capuccino around here. Forget it. This '11 be fine.
answer: I wonder what the weather's going to be like for all the festivities.

question: My guess is it'11 be cold and overcast, high today in the low 30's, dropping to the low 20's tonight, but I'm predicting that all that moisture coming up from the Gulf is going to miss us and dump some locally heavy snow, possibly blizzard conditions with travel advisories in the Harrisburg area and maybe as far east as .Philadelphia. (off her surprised Unfortunately yes. Phil exits.
answer: Phil! Phil Connors! I thought that was you! Phil looks at him vaguely.

question: I 'm sorry. Have we-- uh--
answer: My oh my! Phil Connors. Don't say you don't remember me, 'cause I sure as heckrfire remember you. Well? Phil stares, trying to remember. Ned Ryerson? Needlenose Ned? Ned the Head. Come on, buddy. Case Western High?

question: Ned?
answer: I see you clicking through that brain of yours. Click-click, c li ck- cli ck, click-click--Bing! Ned Ryerson, did the whistling trick with my belly button in the talent show. Bing! Ned Ryerson, got the shingles real bad senior ^year^ almost didn't graduate. Bing again! Ned Ryerson, went out with your sister Mary Pat a couple of times-- 'til you told me not to anymore. Well? Bing!

question: So what're you doing with yourself, Ned?
answer: Phil, I sell insurance.

question: No kidding.
answer: Do you have life insurance, Phil? 'Cause if you do, I bet you could u s e more-- who couldn't?--but I got a feeling you don't have any. Am I right?

question: You know, Ned, I ' d love to talk to you but I really have to-- Phil starts to walk away,,but Ned won't take the hint.
answer: That's okay. I'll walk with you. When I see an opportunity, I charge it, like a bull. Ned the Bull, that's me now. Some of my friends live and die by actuarial tables, but I think it's all just a crap shoot anyhoo. Ever heard of single .premium life? That could be the ticket for you, buddy. God, it's good to see you! Hey, what're you doing for dinner?

question: Dinner? Umm, I don't think that's going to work for me. As they continue walking, Phil steps into what looks like a shallow puddle and ends up ankle deep in wet slush. Ned laughs like a donkey.
answer: Hey, look out for that first step! It's a doozy! Phil looks at him with murderous contempt.

question: How could he be late?
answer: Prima donnas.

question: It's just so-- inconsiderate.
answer: What happens to some people? They're born nice. They grow up nice. You put 'em on TV and - bam! Prima donnas. Rita spots Phil heading into the crowd.

question: Here he comes. Phil! Hey, Phil. Over here! Phil joins them in the press area. Rita pulls him to his mark near the rail fence. Where've you been?
answer: I got hung up with some jerk I went to high school with. So, did you sleep okay without me? You tossed and turned, didn't you? Rita holds up a slate for Larry to ID the tape.

question: You're incredible.
answer: Who told you?

question: Once a year, the eyes of the nation turn here, to this tiny hamlet in Pennsylvania, to watch a master at work. The master? Punxsutawney Phil, the world's most famous weatherman, the groundhog, who, as legend has it, can predict the coming of an early spring. Rita turns to Larry. This is impressive-- so far, so good. A Groundhog Club Official kneels at the burrow and ceremoniously knocks on the small wooden door, then opens it and retreats. And here's the big moment we've all been waiting for. Let's just see what Mr. Groundhog has to say. The groundhog sticks his head out, looks around, steps out of the hole, and runs over to the other side of the mound, about as far away from the cameras as he can get. Hey! Over here, you little weasel! Larry zooms in as far as he can but the best he can manage is a close-up of the groundhog's back. The groundhog stands there a moment, his body casting a long shadow, then he lets out a squeak and runs back into the hole. Great shot, huh, folks? Well, that was certainly worth the trip. Now we'll be hearing from Mr. Buster Greene, President of the Punxsutawney Groundhog Club, the so-called Seer of Seers who will interpret for us. BUSTER GREENE, dressed up in his top hat and cutaway coat, walks onto the mound and hushes the crowd. Well, that's it. Sorry you couldn't be here in person to share the electric moment. This is one event where televison really fails to capture the excitement of thousands of people gathered to watch a large squirrel predict the weather, and I for one am deeply grateful to have been a part of it. Reporting for Channel 9, this is Phil Connors. Larry cuts the camera.
answer: You want to try one that's a little sweeter?

question: That's as sweet as I get. I'm outa here. As he exits, Phil tosses the mike to Larry, who isn't expecting the throw and bobbles it, dropping the mike on the ground.
answer: That was really lousy.

question: Is it my fault the little rat went south on us?
answer: A real professional would have handled it. You acted like it was a personal insult. Who do you think you are -- Wolf Blitzer?

question: God, you really take this stuff seriously, don't you.
answer: Yes, I do. As far as I ' m concerned there are no little stories, Phil. Only little reporters with big egos who think they're too good for the job they have to do.

question: You really don't know me very well, do you. 'Cause if you did you could never say something like that about me. I care! Call me a cockeyed optimist but I happen to think there's more to this job than just getting my ugly mug on the boob tube every night.
answer: Is that so.

question: I'll call you after I see the network guy. I should be back there in a couple of hours...What?...1 can't hear you-- you're breaking up...Hello? Sabrina? Sabrina ? Can you hear me? Shit! He slams the phone back into it's cradle, then looks up and notices slow traffic up ahead. He honks his horn as the traffic comes to a complete stop. He keeps honking but nothing moves. He rolls down the window and looks up ahead. The highway is a parking lot. No. No! What's going on, Officer? What blizzard? A couple of flakes! An isolated phenomenon of nature. No, no. All that moisture is going to miss us and hit Harrisburg. But I have to get to Pittsburgh today! So all the long distance lines a re down? What about the sa tellite? Is it snowing in space?...But I have to call Pittsburgh...Isn't there some special line you keep open for emergencies or for celebrities?...Well, I'm both really. I'm a celebrity in an emergency. Can you patch me through on that line? You never saw me on TV-- on the news?
answer: I don't think so. What part of the news do you do?

question: I ' m the White House correspondent for NBC news.
answer: Oh , I ' m so sure .

question: Ask me anything?
answer: Okay, how big is the White House?

question: Three bedrooms, two and a half baths. Looks much bigger than it , is. Nancy just stares at him, clearly not into his sense of humor. Suddenly, a BRIDE in full white wedding gown and veil rushes into the bar, crying and shouting. A gaggle of BRIDESMAIDS flutters around her trying to coax her back to her own wedding but she won't budge. Then the GROOM, wearing a bad rented tux, comes storming in and tries to drag her back, until the BEST MAN restrains him and the bridesmaids hustle the bride away. Phil watches the whole drama play out, then turns back to Nancy . Good start. I ' m sure they'll be very happy. So what do you say? You want to play doggie obedience school with me?
answer: Thanks. I'll pass. She gets up to leave.

question: Not hardly. Expect hazardous travel later today with that, you know, blizzard thing --
answer: That "blizzard thing?" Phil turns on the water and splashes some on his face as if trying to wake himself up, vaguely disturbed by the repetition of the broadcast. Oh, here's the report

question: Yes they are, but there's another reason today is very special --
answer: Especially cold --

question: Especially cold, okay, but the big question on everybody's lips -- Phil supplies the next line in unison with the radio. -- on their chapped lips, right -- Do you think Phil's going to come out and see his shadow?
answer: Punxsutawney Phil. Some vague doubt causes Phil to go to the window.

question: Morning.
answer: Morning.

question: Think it'll be an early Spring?
answer: Didn't we do this yesterday? Don't mess with me, pork chop. What day is this? Okay. Sorry. I'm having a bad day. Phil walks on, leaving the chubby man baffled and insulted.

question: Did you sleep well, Mr. Connors?
answer: D i d I? I don't know--

question: Would you like some coffee?
answer: Yes, thank you. I ' m feeling a little strange.

question: I wonder what the weather's going to be like for all the festivities.
answer: Did you ever have deja vu, Mrs. Lancaster?

question: Is that the Italian dessert with the brandy and the chocolate mousse?
answer: No, that's spaghetti. Never mind. He heads for the door, still in a daze.

question: Oh, will you be checking out today, Mr. Connors?
answer: Ma'am? Excuse me. Where's everybody going?

question: Ma'am? Excuse me. Where's everybody going?
answer: Phil! Phil Connors! I thought that was you! Phil just stares at him and keeps walking. My oh my! Phil Connors. Don't say you don't remember me, 'cause I sure as heck-fire remember you. Well?

question: Ned Ryerson?
answer: Bing! First shot right out of the box. So how's it going, ol' buddy?

question: To tell you the truth, Neddy, I ' m not feeling real well. Could you excuse me?
answer: Now it's funny you should mention your health 'cause you'll never guess what I do.

question: Do you sell insurance, Ned?
answer: Bing again! You're sharp as a tack today. Do you have life insurance, Phil? 'Cause if you do, I bet you could use more -- who couldn't?" -- but I got a feeling you don't have any. Am I right?

question: Did I say "fuck off, " Ned? I can't talk to you right now. He backs away from Ned and steps right into the same deep, slushy puddle he stepped in the day before.
answer: Here he comes. Phill Hey, Phil! Over here! Phil waves to her and heads straight for an obscure corner of the Knob, gesturing for her to follow. Larry shakes his head as Rita charges through the crowd toward Phil. She catches up to him just as he is scratching a mark in the snow with his foot. She notices immediately that he is uncharacteristically dishevelled, his tie askew, his hair mussed. Where ' ve you been?

question: I've got to talk to you. I think I'm losing my mind. Slap me, Rita.
answer: What is this?

question: I said hardl Do it! Rita shrugs and slaps him very hard. Better. Almost too hard, Rita.
answer: Are you drunk?

question: No, drunk is more fun. Can I be serious with you for a minute?
answer: I don't know. Can you?

question: Yes. I ' m being serious. I' m having a problem-- no, I may be having a problem.
answer: What are you trying to say?

question: Were not going to miss it. (indicating the other Okay, put it here.
answer: What?

question: Put the camera here . Rita takes a forlorn glance towards the press area, where all of the other cameras are set up .
answer: Phil , there is no tomorrow on this one. It's Groundhog Day.

question: We were in the wrong spot yesterday . Just trust me. Put the camera here .
answer: Larry! She charges off toward the cameras. In the Press Area, several reporters are already talking to their cameras, dribbling on about how "He could appear any second now." Rita and Larry grab their gear and rush back to Phil. Larry hurriedly sets up the camera.

question: I ' m conducting an experiment. (with forced good How was that? Could I talk to you about a matter that is not work related?
answer: You never talk about work.

question: Do you know what I did last night?
answer: Do I want to know?

question: I destroyed my hotel room.
answer: You whatl This is not some kind of rock and roll tour. We don't have the budget for that--

question: No, it's okay. This morning it was all right again. That's what I have to talk to you about.
answer: Phil, what are you doing? Could I have some coffee, please? The waiter pours her a cup. Thanks. Okay, so tell me. How'd you know where to put the camera?

question: Because I've done it before.
answer: I know, but the groundhog doesn't do exactly the same thing every year, does he?

question: I ' m not talking about last year. I ' m talking about today. I lived it before.
answer: You're having deja vu?

question: Big time. Rita, I know it's nuts but I keep reliving the same day o ve r and over-- Groundhog Day-- today. This is the third time.
answer: Uh-huh. I'm waiting for the punchline.

question: No, really. It's like today never happened. I shaved my head last night, today its all grown back. I could probably cut off my limbs, one by one, and - pop! They'd grow back. Just like a starfish. I probably don't even have to floss?
answer: I'm wracking my brain, but I can't even begin to imagine why you'd make up something like this.

question: 'Cause I'm not making it up. I'm asking for your help. Rita looks at him for a long moment.
answer: Okay, I'll bite. What do you want me to do?

question: The truth? I'd 1ike you to spend the next 24 hours with me and don't leave my side for a second.
answer: I see. You know, Phil, you can charm all the little P.A.'s at the station, all the secretaries, and even some of the weekend a nchors, but not me-- not in a thousand years.

question: Wa it a second--
answer: Not if I was dying and your breath was the only cure; not if having your child was the only way to preserve the human race. Just get it out of your head because it is NOT GOING TO

question: That's kind of an unusual problem, Mr. Connors. Most of my work is with couples and families. Phil is lying on a couch. His head is completely shaved.
answer: Yeah, but you're still a psychologist. You must have had some course in school that covered this kind of thing.

question: Sort of, I guess. Abnormal Psychology.
answer: So based on that what would you say? You're saying this thing is not really happening to me?

question: Uh-huh.
answer: Then how do I know this conversation is really happening?

question: I guess you don't.
answer: Then forget about me paying you. A discreet little alarm sounds. Wait! Are you saying I'm crazy?

question: Not necessarily. If it concerns you we should schedule our next session as soon as possible. How's tomorrow for you? Phil glowers at him.
answer: You think that's a realistic possibility? A paper airplane sails past his head, accompanied by a noisy outburst of juvenile laughter. We pull back to REVEAL: Gus, what would you do if there was no tomorrow?

question: What if nothing mattered?! Jeez, I know what I'd do. I ' d j ust spend all my time drivin' fast, gettin1 loaded and gettin' laid. That's it.
answer: That's it. It just doesn't get any better than this, does it? Good friends, good conversation and quality brew. Drink up, boys. They salute each other and drink.

question: (fumbling with his
answer: Hey, friends don't let friends drive drunk. Give me your keys.

question: Thanks , man .
answer: It's nothing. Get in. They all pile into the front seat with Phil at the wheel. Seatbelts. Ralph and Gus give him the thumbs up sign and start digging around in the seat cracks for their seatbelts. Suddenly, Phil floors the accelerator and peels away, sideswiping a parked car as he screeches around the corner. This is great, Ralph!

question: Oh, hey, take a left! Phil passes the intersection. You missed it!
answer: No problem -- So many rules --

question: You can say that again.
answer: "Don't do this--" "Don't do that -- " He mows down a row of parking meters. No more rules!

question: No more rules! That's two!
answer: Having a good time?

question: Hey, uh --
answer: Phil.

question: Yeah, Phil-- like the groundhog.
answer: Right.

question: Ned! Ned Ryerson! Ned the Head! Before Ned can say another word, Phil SLUGS HIM. Ned goes down, Phil puts his glove back on and keeps walking. Phil deftly avoids the slushy pothole he stepped in before. A PEDESTRIAN walking behind him steps right into it. You here to see the groundhog? She gives him a look. It's obvious she's never seen him before.
answer: Can you think of another reason anybody'd be out here at dawn on a freezing day?

question: What's your name?
answer: Nancy Taylor. And you are--

question: Where'd you go to high school?
answer: What is this? Lincoln High school. In Pittsburgh. Who are you?

question: Who was your twelfth grade English teacher?
answer: Are you kidding?

question: I'm waiting.
answer: .Mrs. Walsh.

question: Walsh. Nancy, Lincoln, Walsh.
answer: Is this some kind of come-on?

question: I'm not really sure. We'll have to see. Phil walks off and joins Rita at their camera position.
answer: Is this some new fad diet? Don't you worry about cholesterol? Phil scrapes a plate and takes a final bite of a chocolate eclair.

question: I don't worry about anything anymore.
answer: What makes you so special? Everybody worries about something.

question: That's exactly what makes me so special. He takes a big bite of cake. Rita shakes her head. What?
answer: "The wretch, concentered all in self, Living, shall forfeit fair renown, And doubly dying, shall go down to the vile dust from whence he sprung, Unwept, unhonored, and unsung." Sir Walter Scott.

question: "There was a young man from Na n t uc k e t-- "
answer: That's really funny. When are you going to grow up, Phil?

question: At this rate-- never. (he pulls out a pack of
answer: You really do have a death wish, don't you?

question: Just the opposite, Rita. I have a life wish. I'm just trying to enjoy it. Taking pleasure in the little things. Don't you ever just want to cut loose and go wild?
answer: I wouldn't even know what it means to go wild.

question: Yeah, well, that's where I come in. Going wild is one of my specialties. Last night I got completely loaded and drove head- on into a police car. That's my point. I know you won't believe me, but we could do anything we want today and it wouldn't matter one bit. Absolutely no consequences. Complete and total freedom.
answer: And how. . , do we manage that?

question: You leave that to me. Why don't you send Larry back and hang out with me for the rest of the day? You never make it through that blizzard anyway. Larry enters the diner and spots them.
answer: I'll take my chances with the -weather. But you have a good time.

question: Don't worry. I plan to. Nancy? Nancy turns and looks at him quizzically. Nancy, right?
answer: I'm sorry, I--

question: Nancy Taylor? Lincoln High? I sat next to you in Mrs. Walsh's English class.
answer: T h at --

question: Phil Connors.
answer: --is amazing!

question: You don't remember me, do you?
answer: I don't-- sure, I think--

question: We used to shoot spit balls--
answer: Yeah, oh, God--

question: I even asked you to the prom.
answer: Phil Connors.

question: Yeah.
answer: How ARE you?!

question: I ' m great. Wow, you look terrific. Hey, listen, I gotta d o this report--
answer: You're a reporter?

question: Weatherman. Channel 9, Pittsburgh.
answer: Right, I should've known--

question: But maybe after we could --
answer: Yeah, yeah, I ' d like that --

question: O-rita. Nancy laughs uncertainly. Phil switches off the light, thinking now about Rita.
answer: Isn't it a wonderful collection?

question: Yes, it is. You don't usually find this many trashy novels in one place.
answer: You can take a book up to your room if you like.

question: No, thank you. I've actually read them all. I was just rereading some of the dirty parts. He finishes and puts the book back on the shelf. Indefinitely. I've already been here for 211 days.
answer: Really? That's quite a long time, isn't it. I hope you're finding things to do in our little town.

question: You guys ever been held up before? (they shake their Yeah. By the way, I'm Phil. He raises the mask and shows his face. Herman and Felix. Okay. Take it easy, boys. And thanks. The frightened guards watch as Phil makes off with two large satchels of cash. I'll take it. How much? I'll tell you what. I'll give you $70,000 if you just knock off the car salesman stuff and let me get out of here with my car. The Salesman gawks as Phil opens his briefcase and starts counting out stacks of bills. Yeah, we are, we are. But first I have this movie theater fantasy I want to talk to you about. He escorts her into the theater. Yeah, but eventually you' d just get tired of screwing around and then you'd want a real relationship, wouldn't you? Get down, Brunoi Down , Bruno ! It's tough to find a relationship like that, especially if your time is kind of limited. But you still have to try, don't you? Bruno! I told you! Off the bed! Phil looks over at Angle who's passed out with her mouth open There ' s got to be more to it than this.
answer: You look good. I mean, it came o ut all right. How'd you know where to put the camera?

question: Psychic. So did you have a nice evening? I got my whole body tattooed and part ied all night with some nymphomaniac biker chicks. No, they're gone. Rita, if you only had one day to live, what would you do with it?
answer: I don't know, Phil. What are you dying of?

question: No, I mean like what if the entire world was about to explode?
answer: I ' d just want to know where to p ut the camera. What are you looking for, Phil-- a date for the weekend? She starts walking toward the center of town. Phil sticks right with her.

question: No, I just want to know you better. What do you like, what do you want, what do you think about, what kind of men are you interested in, what do you do for fun?
answer: Is this real or are you just going to make me feel like a fool?

question: I'm just trying to talk to you like a normal person. Isn't this how normal people talk?
answer: Close.

question: Okay, so talk to me. C'mon, I'll buy you a cup of coffee.
answer: I guess I want what everybody wants-- you know, career, love, marriage, children. So far I don't have any of it.

question: You have a career.
answer: I have a job. Doing stories on the Punxsutawney groundhog is not my ultimate goal. No offense.

question: How about the other stuff? You seeing anybody?
answer: This is getting too personal. I don't think I ' m ready to discuss these things with you. What about you? What do you want?

question: What I really want is someone like you.
answer: O h , please--

question: Why not?
answer: Phil, you know, you have so much talent and ability. If you'd just drop the attitude and act like a decent human being, then maybe I ' d --

question: You'd what?
answer: I don't know what.

question: Then maybe you'd like me? She stares hard at him.
answer: I don't know. It's sort of like the way I feel about UFO's. I'd have to see it to believe it. Larry pokes his head in the doorway, looks around, spots Rita and makes his way over to their table.

question: Yeah, I'll be right out, Larry. Larry scowls at Phil and exits.
answer: Why don't you stay for a while? The road's going to be closed anyway. Do you really want to be stuck in the van with Larry for three hours?

question: I've got to get back. I'll see you later. Phil watches Rita exit.
answer: Well, you heard it right from the groundhog's mouth. Bundle up good, 'cause it's going to be a long winter-- at least in Punxsutawney. Reporting for Channel 9, this is Phil Connors. Larry stops tape.

question: That was great. How did you know
answer: Oh, hi, Rita. You still here?

question: Okay.
answer: Jack Daniels.

question: Tequila,with lime. Gold, if you've got it. Phil nods to himself.
answer: Oh, hi, Rita. You still here? Wouldn't you know it. Buy you a drink?

question: Okay.
answer: Tequila with lime, gold if you've got it. Rita looks at Phil, surprised.

question: Same for me, please. The BARTENDER pours.
answer: What should we toast to?

question: Your call.
answer: To the groundhog! Rita stares for a moment.

question: I always drink to world peace.
answer: Tequila with lime, gold if you've got it. Rita looks at Phil.

question: Same for me, please. The BARTENDER pours. Phil lifts his glass.
answer: To world peace. Rita smiles, reevaluating him.

question: To world peace. They clink glasses.
answer: You like your job?

question: It's okay. I think it could be really challenging. Of course it's about a million miles from where I started out in college.
answer: You weren't in broadcasting?

question: At Bryn Mawr? No, uh-uh. "Believe it or not, I studied Nineteenth Century French Poetry.
answer: Really? What a waste of time. Rita looks offended. Phil knows he made a mistake. You weren't in broadcasting?

question: At Bryn Mawr? No, uh-uh. Believe it or not, I studied Nineteenth Century French Poetry. Phil leans in closer to her.
answer: La fille qui j'aimera Sera comme bon vin Qui se bonifiera Un peut chaque matin. Rita smiles, entranced.

question: This is terrific.
answer: Best fudge in town.

question: How do you know so much about Punxsutawney?
answer: I like small towns. I think they engender real community more than big cities.

question: That is so true! I've always thought that, too.
answer: No kidding. Here-- try the white chocolate.

question: Oh, yuk, don't make me sick.
answer: No white chocolate.

question: What?
answer: I ' m just amazed. And I'm not easily amazed.

question: About what?
answer: How you can start a day with one kind of expectation and end up so completely different.

question: Do you like how this day is turning out?
answer: Yes. I like it very much. They stop dn front of Phil's hotel. She turns to him. You could never have planned a day like this, but it couldn't have been more perfect.

question: You're wrong. I've been planning this day for weeks. Rita ignores the remark and hugs him. Phil tries to kiss her but she gently puts her fingers to his lips, stopping him. \ They enter the bed and breakfast inn.
answer: Thanks. See you tomorrow.

question: Tomorrow? Wait, aren't you going to come up to my room for a while?
answer: I don't know, Phil--

question: Noreason to end a perfect day. No, you should. The, uh, the poetry! I've got some books, Rimbaud, Beaudelaire, we could l ig ht a fire--
answer: Thanks, but --

question: (seeing it all slip But there is no tomorrow for me! Why not? Rita, I love you!
answer: You don't even know me!

question: Please! You have to! Rita shakes loose from his grasp.
answer: What's wrong with you! There is a long moment of silent tension, then all her old doubts about Phil come rushing back. Oh, no. I can't believe I fell for it. This whole day was just one long set-up. And I ate fudge. Yucchh! I hate fudge.

question: No, it was real. I love you.
answer: Stop saying that! Do you really expect me to trust you? The whole secretarial pool is a Phil Connors recovery group.

question: But I can change! I really can-- Rita slaps him hard on the cheek.
answer: That's for making me care about you. She turns and stomps off, leaving Phil standing there hurting.

question: I ' m sorry. What was that again?
answer: I'm a god.

question: You're God?
answer: No, I'm A god. Not THE God-- at least I don't think I am.

question: That's reassuring. For a mintute there I thought you might be crazy.
answer: No, it's true. It's the only possible explanation. I'm a supernatural being.

question: This is some kind of trick.
answer: Yes, it's a trick. But maybe the real God cheats, too. Maybe God isn't omnipotent-- he's just had a lot of practice.

question: How about that guy?
answer: Tom. Worked in the coal mine til they shut it down.

question: Her? How do you know these people!
answer: I told you the truth. In five seconds there's going to be a grease fire in the kitchen. Five, four--

question: This is nuts.
answer: --three, two, one. Phil points to the kitchen as smoke starts pouring from the service window. Everyone in the diner is now staring at them

question: (trying to puzzle it
answer: I know all about you, Rita. I know you like producing, but hope for better than Channel 9, Pittsburgh.

question: Everyone knows that.
answer: You like boats but not the ocean. There's a lake you go to in the summer with your family, up in the mountains, with an old wooden dock and a boathouse with boards missing in the roof, and a place you used to crawl underneath to be alone, and at night you'd look up and see the stars. You're a sucker for Rocky Road, Marlon Brando, and French poetry. You're wonderfully generous; you're kind to strangers, and children; and when you stand in the snow, you look like an angel.

question: How are you doing this?
answer: I told you! I wake up every day right here, right in Punxsutawney, and it's always February second and I can't turn it off. If you still don't bel iev e me, listen--

question: B u t , Phil--
answer: Listen! In ten seconds Larry is going to walk through that door and take you away from me.

question: Larry?
answer: But you can't let him. Please believe me. You've got to believe me.

question: I don't -- Larry pokes his head in the doorway, looks around and spots Rita.
answer: Look. As Rita turns around to see Larry, Phil grabs a pen and pad from a passing waitress and quickly writes something down as Larry makes his way to their table. Phil finishes writing.

question: I don't know. I just woke up. Just like always. NED RY-ERSON approaches.
answer: Hey, Phil! Phil Connors 1

question: Rita, this is Ned Ryerson. He's an asshole.
answer: He remembers me! Phil and Rita keep walking. Rita looks back at Ned, perplexed

question: Trust me on that one.
answer: This is great.

question: No, it isn't. You hate fudge. I told you. I know everybody. Rita stops walking.
answer: Did we ever...you know? Come on.

question: You're European trained, aren't you. Phil continues walking. You weren't interested.
answer: Not that it would've been so awful.

question: I understand.
answer: I just had to know whether to smack you or not.

question: You did.
answer: Good.

question: So do you believe any of this?
answer: I don't know. I don't know how else you could know so much. Maybe it is really happening.

question: I used to try to stay up all night sometimes. I thought if I could stay conscious I could figure out what was going on, or at least hang onto something from the day before. But I gave up on that a long time ago. Rita looks at him with compassion.
answer: It sounds so-- lonely.

question: (trying to shrug it
answer: Maybe I should spend the rest of the day with you-- as an objective witness. Just to see what happens. Okay?

question: Yeah, sure. That'd be okay. It's not in the wrist so much as the fingers. Be the hat.
answer: It would take me a year to get good at this.

question: Uh-uh. Six months. Four, five hours a day.
answer: Is this what you do with eternity?

question: Now you know. It's like waiting for a bus that never comes . You should see me play pool -- and bowling, juggling, hacky sack. I can ride a unicycle. There ' s a knock on the door . I'll get it! Phil jumps for the door and opens it. The PIZZA GUY is there. Hi, Marty. $11.75 including the delivery charge, right?
answer: MMMM. Pepperoni and olives. My favorite .

question: Of course. I told you, I know everything .
answer: (taking a bite of

question: That's not the worst part.
answer: What's the worst part?

question: The worst part is starting over everyday. Tomorrow you won't remember any of this. You'll go back to treating me like a complete jerk --
answer: No --

question: It's not your fault. I am a jerk.
answer: No, you're not.

question: Okay, I ' m not. It really doesn't make a lot of difference. I've killed myself so many times, I don't even exist anymore. I'm just completely empty.
answer: Or completely clean.

question: If you're going to be this positive all the time I may have to rough you up a little.
answer: Wait! Have we done this before?

question: Which part?
answer: You getting me up here, the card gam e, the pizza--

question: No, this is the first time. Well, what?
answer: Well how does it feel to be doing something completely new? Phil looks at her with tremendous affection and gratitude.

question: Good. Really good. He takes a slice of pizza and starts eating with gusto.
answer: Sometimes I wish I had a thousand lifetimes. One to be a great journalist. One to, I don't know, go back to school, study art, or auto mechanics. One just to take care of all the busywork, you know, pay the bills, get my car tuned up. One to be the wild woman of Borneo. One to be Mother Theresa. Maybe it's not a curse, Phil. It all just depends on how you look at it. Phil stares at her for a long time letting this sink in. Then he belches really loud. Rita stares at him, then burps surprisingly loud herself. I want you to know, it's been a really nice day for me.

question: Me, too.
answer: Maybe, if it's not too boring for you, we could do it again.

question: I hope so. The clock reads 11:59. Rita grabs Phil's hand. He puts his arm around her. They look into each others' eyes. Rita gives Phil a reassuring smile. She squeezes his hand. Their eyes turn to the clock. 11:;59 turns to 12:00. Rita looks up at Phil as if expecting some magical event.
answer: You're still here!

question: I know.
answer: I thought you were supposed to disappear-- or I was or something.

question: Not 'til six.
answer: You rat!

question: I never said midnight--
answer: You knew I was waiting for midnight!

question: But I never said it.
answer: Oh, I can't believe you! (she slugs him with a

question: Does that mean you're going?
answer: No. Phil takes Rita's hand. She doesn't resist. I'm sorry.

question: It's okay to go to sleep you know. I promise I won't touch you-- much.
answer: No, it's all right. I'm not tired. What were you saying? Her eyes start to close again.

question: I was saying that the cow was eventually returned to it's rightful owner.
answer: Really?

question: That's right. He looks at her, sees she's truly asleep, and gently maneuvers her into a comfortable reclining position on the bed. Then he carefully puts a pillow under her head and settles down next to her. What I was going to say was, I think you're the kindest, sweetest, prettiest, most wonderful girl I ever met in my life. She starts to stir but he gently kisses her back to sleep. Shhhh. That's good. (satisfied she's still I know a guy like me could never deserve to have someone like you, but if I did, I swear I would love you for the rest of my life. Rita opens her eyes. Good-night, Rita. He kisses her gently on the forehead.
answer: Good-night, Phil.

question: Rita? She looks at him without a trace of the rapport they shared the night before.
answer: Oh, hi, Phil.

question: Thought you might like some-- He hands her the coffee.
answer: Thanks!

question: We're just setting up.
answer: You know, I bumped into Buster Greene, he kind of runs this thing, and he tipped me off that we might get a better shot over there.

question: Really?
answer: I mean, maybe we should go for it. What do you think?

question: I'll get that. Phil helps Larry carry the camera gear. You and I never talk, Larry. You got kids? Larry looks suspicious. Rita looks on, reevaluating Phil. Where would I find the Philosophy section?
answer: Yes?

question: I ' d like a piano lesson, please.
answer: Oh. Okay, I ' m with a student now, but --

question: I'll give you a thousand dollars. Mary hesitates only a moment, then ushers Phil into the house and closes the door. A moment later the door opens and a LITTLE GIRL with an armloa of music books exits as if pushed. The door closes behind her.
answer: Morning.

question: Buon Giorno, signore.
answer: Think it ' 11 be an early Spring?

question: "Winter slumbering in the open air wears on his smiling face a dream of Spring."
answer: Oh.

question: Technically, yes. Phil plays on, definitely improving.
answer: Phil stands in front of the camera, giving his report.

question: In fact, the groundhog's legendary ability to predict the weather may be more than just the German folklore of the region. Higher temperatures trigger hormonal changes in the testosterone levels of male groundhogs, which may in fact wake them from hibernation and send them out to battle with other males ;for mating rights. So, the truth is they're not looking for their shadows, they're looking for groundhog chicks. Rita looks on, clearly delighted with the report.
answer: Phil is delivering another report.

question: But what if the rules changed? What if none of your actions had consequences?
answer: There would still be an absolute morality. There has to be an absolute good, regardless of the circumstances.

question: Oh, is that so, Miss Plato? Then let me ask you this. Where does this "absolute good" come from? From the sky?
answer: I don't know. From my freshman Philosophy course, I guess. They both laugh. Then she looks at him for a long moment and grins.

question: What?
answer: Nothing. I just can't believe you're such a fine sculptor. Phil takes a bite of her apple and gets up.

question: I gotta go.
answer: Where do you have to go in Punxsutawney?

question: I got piano and then drums.
answer: Here?

question: One day. I'm gifted. Hey, mister. Hey. Come on, let's get you somewhere warm. The old bum turns to look at Phil, then closes his eyes. There you go. Phil practically carries him out of the alley.
answer: You the one brought in the old man?

question: How is he?
answer: He passed away just now. Phil pauses for a long moment.

question: What'd he die of? I want to see his chart. Excuse me. Phil brushes past her and makes for the big double doors leading to triage.
answer: Sir, you can't -- Look! Some people just die!

question: Try the curlycue fries. Killer.
answer: Looks like insulin shock. She's probably diabetic. Phil enters wearing a doctor's scrub suit and begins barking orders.

question: She's not diabetic. It's an overdose. Let's get her up here and pump her stomach, then I want a complete blood work-up, STAT.
answer: R i g h t , Doctor--uh-- She realizes she's never seen him before.

question: Call me Phil.
answer: Phil. Like the groundhog?

question: Exactly. A giraffe? Let's see. It's just like a dog with a biiiiig-- what was it? A big tail? Okay, a big tail. There. A dog with long legs. Oh! Right! A dog with a big head.
answer: All right, now what's going on?

question: Come on. We have to hurry. That little bastard has never thanked me once . I ought to j ust let him fall. Teach him a lesson.
answer: Phil, this is too -- I must be dreaming.

question: Yeah, you and me both. Come on, We're almost done.
answer: Is he -- ? In a minute. She waits and watches. The paramedics, BUD and ANDY, get out of the ambulance and inspect the scene. May I see that? "Every night, by cold bricks Now what?

question: Come on. You'll see. They enter.
answer: This is incredible. Who's wedding is this?

question: I don ' t understand . You rush from one person to the next in a town you only visit once a year, you know everything before it happens , and you -- - I don ' t know , you seem to be Punxsutawney ' s leading citizen. The band finishes a set. The guests stop dancing and head for the refreshments. Phil and Rita are left alone for the moment
answer: What do you want to know?

question: Who are you?
answer: I really don't know.

question: No, there's something going on with you.
answer: Okay, I wake up in Punxsutawney on February second -- every day. It's supernatural. I don't even try to explain it anymore. So, I live each day as if it's the only day I've got. Rita stares into his eyes for a very long time, but sees only good, true things.

question: That's pretty amazing. "
answer: You want to know what's really amazing? I've been waiting for you every day for ten thousand years. I dream of you every night of my life. You've been my constant weapon against total despair, and just knowing you exist has kept me alive. How's that? Rita can't even speak. This is clearly the nicest thing anybody has ever said to anybody. Mary the piano teacher notices Phil.

question: Do ctor Connors?
answer: Wait! Don't move!

question: Making a snow man? I'll help.
answer: No, stay there. Stand right th ere.

question: Can I look?
answer: O kay, look. This is how I see you. When it all gets too much, I just close my eyes and there you are-- just like this. Take it home and keep it in the freezer. Rita embraces Phil. They are about to kiss, looking deep into each others eyes. This one's for the Frog Prince.

question: What?
answer: Nothing. They kiss-- a long, deep, soul-stirring kiss. Will you come with me? Rita nods. They continue standing there, embracing, warming each other in the cold night air.

question: (looks back at the ice
answer: It doesn't matter. Really, it doesn't. They kiss again. You're here! My god! I can't believe you're here!

question: Glad to see you, too.
answer: No! It's happened. Don't you get it? It's tomorrow! It's -- Phil turns on the radio.

question: I love those guys.
answer: Are you always this jolly in the morning? Phil runs to the window and looks out.

question: No groundhog! Rita! They're all gone!
answer: You must've had some dream. Phil stops, thinks.

question: Did I just dream it? Phil opens the door and runs into the hallway wearing only pajama bottoms.
answer: Phi l? Phil! Rita sits up in bed and waits. Suddenly, from somewhere else in the inn comes the sound of Phil at the piano expertly playing a difficult classical piece. He stops after a few bars.

question: Yeah!!!! Phil runs back into the room. It really happened! You're really here! He pounces on Rita again. You're really actually here. Let's go! He scoops her up in his arms.
answer: Where're we going?

question: Anywhere! Everywhere!
answer: Oh, my!

question: Florence! Say hello to Rita. She loves me.
answer: I'm not surprised. He kisses her on the cheek and rushes out with Rita.
